Pros:
- Flexibility in working arrangements 
- Health care packages
- You're working for #1 
- The name carries a lot of kudos, doesn't matter who you talk to in business, you mention Cisco and it does command a level of respect and appreciation
Cons:
- Slow progression. Essentially you're up against everyone else within your pay grade for a promo. That can potentially be a lot of people you have to our maneuver for extra dosh.
- Cultural shift in recent years towards loud and brash "sell, sell, sell" model, away from raw engineering and capability, that arguably made Cisco what it is today. 
- Almost too large now for engineers to be taken seriously unless they are architects / systems engineers or very senior and even then that's probably giving those folk too much credit. 
- Can be political but so can every work place

Pros:
I started my career in the CSAP program, coming directly from University. From the beginning I had tremendous support and felt the positive vibe in the company. You are always encouraged and empowered to find own solutions. I have always felt an incredible amount of trust - which let you simply grow. But if you ask for help - there will always someone available to help.
The culture is very supportive - not only on the professional, but also on the private life. Being a mother myself it helps to have a home office and flexible working hours to balance family and Cisco. 
Cisco deeply cares about giving back - every employee gets additional 5 days annually for local giving back activities. It is so inspirational to get this opportunity.
Cons: This culture works probably not for everybody. You have to have a sense of purpose for yourself and drive your own projects. If you prefer to have a detailed description and predefined steps what you have to do - Cisco is probably not the right company for you. In order to be successful you have to be self motivated, creative and the courage to succeed. And since you are so empowered - it can also be difficult to limit yourself to healthy work hours. You will be encouraged to care for yourself naturally - nevertheless there is no "clocking in / clocking out", hence there is always something to do - and you need to be able to set yourself healthy limits.

Pros: Cisco is a forward-looking company, but execution does sometimes get wrapped around the axle of politics. Cisco manages to stay where it is through the occasional big technology breakthrough, like Encrypted Traffic Analytics and thanks to brand, heft, and the fact that no one ever got fired for buying Cisco. The company is making good progress now in their transformation from a products company to a software/subscriptions company. This is an amazing accomplishment that should be credited to Chuck Robbins and his management team. While John Chambers grew a behemoth from a strong up-and-comer, and was a wizard at integration of acquisitions (for the most part), but he could not make this transformation, though he'd tried for years. It's a company with a bright future in cloud and security.
Cons: Too many decisions are made because of the HiPPO (Highest Paid Person's Opinion), whether or not it's the right thing to do. Look at key competitors from Zoom to Juniper to see talented folks who took their good ideas elsewhere and peeled off market share.

Pros:
Work hours seem to be 9:00am - 4:45pm (4:15pm on Fridays) so you are able to keep a work-life balance for the most part.
Nice friendly colleagues.
If you keep your head down, don't rock the boat, and don't think outside the box, you'll do fine.
Cons:
Rewards & recognition are hard to come by - you have to work the political game well to get management recognition for your work.
Upward mobility is also very hard to achieve with entrenched employees and very little movement, other than horizontal.
You are judged not on how well you do your work, but on who you know and your political clout.
A very passive-aggressive workforce who will smile in your face and agree with you, then undermine you and not help - only unless it serves them in their political gain.
Employee Monsters are easily recognizable, but are allowed to wreak havoc because management avoids all possible conflict (see: passive-aggressive)
Definitely an old-school mentality to go along with it's stereotypical "cubeville" work environment.

Pros:
- Great work-life balance, and very open culture between colleagues and various teams
- Everyone in the team is very supportive of each other, and always keen to share best practices and their own experiences
- Customer Success is a new team in Cisco, but we are seeing large support from the CEO and Sales Leaders as Cisco makes the shift to selling more recurring revenue solutions. This is definitely the fastest growing team; and possibly where there is good career growth!
Cons:
A lot of KPIs that the management is pushing for in a bid to prove the value of the Customer Success team.  Cisco is a sales organization, so there is large pressure for creation of expand opportunities. Even though there is so much push to get those KPIs fulfilled, people on the ground are limited due to the strange way in which the expand opportunities are measured.  This is especially difficult in APJ region due to resistance from internal stakeholders. 

Everyone in the team came in very excited and motivated about Customer Success, but I am seeing some level of disillusionment and exhaustion to keep up with ever-changing performance measures, tools, new offers with little to no time to adjust, and high pressure from the managers.

Also experiencing "growing pains" with large number of new members in the team.
There have been layoffs and budget cuts for a while and that means that salary raises havent been that great

Pros:
They trust you to get you job done with little supervision.  I can usually set the times I travel and develop my own pace of what I want to work on.  Usually I can set my schedule up to a month out and I will know what I'm working on.  Managers work with you to ensure that you are helping you and the bottom line of Cisco.

I also like the flexible hours and the allowance of working from my home.  Many times I will not get inspired until late at night and I will work in to the early morning.  As long as I meet my commitments for the next day, Cisco supports me working when I need to.
Cons: Little guidance on what it takes to get promoted to the next level.  Many companies have this problem where they have fuzzy guidance as to what it really takes to move up to the next level.  I think this is a problem for those that are task oriented (as that is one of the skills Cisco Hires).  If there were a specific matrix that helped guide people to where they want to be in 3-5 years and even 10 years out, then Cisco would have a world class system of retaining people as one would always know where one's career is going.

Pros: Cisco is a huge company and you can spend a career jumping from group to group every few years and never work on the same thing over again. Despite what a lot of the reviews here claim Cisco does pay what they should be paying. Some of the business units within Cisco treat their employees better than others and it would be wise to interview with more than one if you're considering a switch to Cisco.
Cons: Cisco is a huge company and you can spend a year drowning in bureaucracy and fighting for change within groups that refuse to do things any better than they ever have before. Some engineers at Cisco are incredibly smart whereas other engineers are incredibly dense. Cisco prefers quantity over quality not only in their employees but also in their products. Shipping a half-baked product on a silly schedule to meet some arbitrary marketing deadlines just seems wrong. No one at Cisco seems to care that their products have a terrible reputation and without the brand recognition no one would buy them. Cisco India (Bangalore) is definitely focused on keeping seats warm rather than building a quality engineering force.

Pros: Good benefit, completive scalars, flexible working schedules.
Cons: Has all the problems that a big company has. The company tried to change this by introducing a CDO college new hire program, and hoping the fresh blood can give more momentum to Cisco. But the result is just the opposite as what it was designed for originally. At first the screening process of the CDO program is too easy. Lots of new hire coming through this program are very high paid without a matching quality. And once they are choosen by the CDO program, they are offered to free pick any group to work for within Cisco. A lots of managers love to get them, just because the first year budge if coming from the company, not the BU. And the following years, if you got more people, you got more budgets. But very often the team can not swallow this much new college grades and sometimes the group doesn’t even have much work for them to do at all. So many of them end up sitting around, and picking up the bad culture of Cisco quickly, This further ruins the culture at Cisco, as an indirect result of it many senior and well experienced people are leaving Cisco.

Pros: I have been with Cisco for 3 years and I believe overall that this is an outstanding company to work for. This is the first company I have worked for that actually recognizes, values and *compensates* you for hard work. And if you prove to management your value and contributions to the overall company, they will absolutely take care of you when it comes to things such as relocation, education, and schedule flexibility. Since collaboration technologies are a huge part of the business model, there are a lot of remote work options (i.e. work from home, road, etc.) - but this depends on your exact role in the company.
Cons: The dreaded "work/life" balance is probably the number one complaint across Cisco employees but it is what you make of it. I know plenty of people that work at Cisco and maintain a pretty close 8-5 work schedule and are highly productive; I know others that work seemingly all hours of the day and night. It's up to you, setting the level of expectation and how efficient you are. But it is extremely easy to get very wrapped up with work and leave little time for anything else.

Pros:
- Good pay
- Good benefits
- Very socially conscious and progressive on important issues
- People are very friendly
Cons:
- Leadership is a mess and has no idea what is happening in the field and what reality is
- We build products that we think the market needs vs what they are actually asking for. So many old egos that will not let bad products fade away
- Just working through all the internal challenges within Cisco to sell is harder than even selling to the customer
- We pay executives tons of money, but cut all the quality out of TAC so it is not good anymore
- We over promise and under deliver all the time. Ask customers to spend like they are buying a Lexus, but they are buying junker
- Way too many people who want their voices and opinions heard and so good ideas turn into terrible execution
- We hire the same people over and over again that are in the same industry or have friends here, instead of finding great talent that can be taught the technology

Pros: Great benefits. Telecommuting. Education and growth potential.
Cons:
They will lay you off at the drop of a hat. I lived through several but didn't duck fast enough for the latest one.
The growth potential is also highly touted but the actual execution still fails due to politics and favoritism.

Pros: Remuneration is very strong and they don't expect you to compromise your life. In fact, they enable you to have a better work/ life balance by providing the equipment and ways of working so you can be highly effective from home. I work 4 days per week from home on average (I have the option to work fewer if I want to). Cisco offers all the benefits you'd expect including you birthday as an additional day off, a choice of high end Mac or PC, phone bill paid in full, 5 additional days off to volunteer for the organisation of your choice (this year I'm using mine to go on a long cycling trip for a charity started by one of my colleague's. You can also receive connected recognition, this is a cash reward of varying amounts you receive from colleagues who think you went above and beyond. I received one last month for £70 but the amounts can be over £100. Aside from all of this, the people are great and together we make a fun friendly culture. It's work hard, play hard and Cisco certainly rewards all those who do. A great choice of tech company whether you have technical skills or not.
Cons: The business is focused on short-term financial performance. This can be frustrating when trying to deliver longer term projects.

Pros:
- CISCO work culture is Open and inclusive.
Open: There are no barriers or inherent hierarchy that limits an employee from reaching out to peers or seniors. The culture encourages collaboration, learning and gives the employee a place to broaden their horizons in terms of theirs skills and knowledge.
Inclusive: CISCO believes in inclusive environment where everyone gets equal opportunity to grow and develop. It is not only inclusive in terms of people but also in terms of growth in recreational activities like sports and arts. It is quite difficult to find such a culture in other companies in India.
- Awesome benefits: The benefits provided by CISCO is by far the best that I have known. The benefits include Health coverage for Family (yourself, spouse, children and parents or in-laws). This is quite rare compared to other companies health benefits. Free GYM, periodic health checkups for yourself, family and parents. Extremely well maintained sports facilities for shuttle, cricket, volley ball and basketball and various others. It supports tuition fee refund for any education/course you take.
- Good Personal and Professional life balance: The work culture is flexible and allows the employee to maintain a balanced personal and professional life. Managers are very understanding and in general the management encourages the employee to ensure a good balance in work and personal life.
Cons: The hike and promotion cycle is fixed. The employee has to finish a certain period of time before being considered for a hike or promotion. This doesn't correspond to the work done by him/her.

Pros:
- Executive leadership communicates honestly and openly

 - The company promotes lateral movement and promotion to both cultivate internal talent and prevent attrition

 - Leadership has a keen sense of the organization's strengths and weaknesses 

 - Evolving product lines and strategic acquisitions outpace product commoditization

 - An emphasis is placed on the customer journey - even if employees on the ground ignore it. 

 - Most of the people I met enjoyed their job, genuinely wanted to add value, and came across as open and collaborative.

 - Clear limits are put in place to make sure that customers are fully supported when new products are introduced. I can't overstate how refreshing this was.
Cons:
- Sales teams seem to be split into warring factions.  This, coupled with a  lack of clear structure leads to a lot of redundancy, wasted resources, and ambiguous goals. The end result is a hamster wheel of day-to-day fire drills. 

 - For all of the talk about customer focus, most employees seem to be obsessed with internal politics.

Pros:
The company has great benefits and seems to truly care about their employees. There is lots of opportunities inside and the work-life balance its ok.
100% remote and flexible time.

Benefits:
-Childcare vouchers
-Annual bonus
-Pension Plan
-Stocks (discount of 15% for employees)
-Health insurance (extended to family, partner and descendents)
-Life insurance (42x base salary)
-All cisco certifications and trainings available and paid by cisco
-Training platforms (o'reilly, linkedin videos, udemy, harvard training, Pluralsight, MasterClass, Coursera,getAbstract)
-400 euros to spend on personal classes, health, medicines, etc
-Car and gas for tech leads (grade 11),
Cons:
The management is really poor.
Everyone that wants to be a manager can become one. It doesn't matter if you'll be a good manager or not, if you want you just work your way out to it. And that's how you become a bad manager and end-up ruining a whole team :)

The problem is that we have lazy and poor managers, managing senior and high performing engineers.

By micro managing, tons of bureaucratic processes and lack of transparency makes the life of engineers frustrating and pretty damn boring.

But it's a matter of luck, I had one good manager, a so-so manager, and now a terrible manager, so good luck with that.

This lack of transparency and bureaucracy is making cisco lose the best talent to other top companies and competitors, but the guys in the top probably don't see that.

Well I like the company, I like the colleagues, but don't trust the management and specially my manager, that's why I'm looking to move out :)

Pros:
Decent benefits
Looks good on resume
Was great until about 2003-4, but has slid downhill since.
Cons:
Boxborough is full of dead wood. Most of the talented people have left or are itching to.
Zero balance between work and home life. It's 24/7 stress due to an oversized workload, undersized staff, and too many people who are mediocre at their jobs.
Fair or not, there's a perception from other locations that San Jose is full of people who get paid for doing very little. It's all who you know. For sure the company is dominated by the IOS group, none of whom seem to understand software developement.
Brain-dead stress on metrics is driving the company and leading to ridiculous behaviors...example: rating managers weekly on their bug counts, while concurrently outsourcing QA to a third party in India where workers performance is based on how many bugs they find: you can guess what happened.
Morale at Boxborough extremely low. Then corporate came up with the PULSE employee satisfaction survey and tied it back-door to managers' compensation. So now the managers are mad at the rank and file for being unhappy. I know one manager that actually made his people take the survey twice with an unsubtle threat that they'd better score "happier" next time.

Pros: Great benefits, very competitive salaries, wide range of directions available in a big company.  As a well established high-tech company Cisco attracts top talent with a great benefits package.  On the whole Cisco looks after its employees and provides good facilities.
Cons: Limited opportunity to innovate, corporate politics, demoralizing business model.  Being head-quartered in the USA, Cisco has a very American approach, and it is difficult to influence company direction or progress through the corporate ladder without spending time working in San Jose.  Working in the UK often means calls and conferences well into the evening, long hours, and a heavy impact on your personal-life.  The company acquires businesses with large market-shares and then implements cost savings, this results in missed opportunities to grow markets and innovate and a feeling of not being engaged with the market or end-customer.

Pros:
-The rotational aspect of the program is great in that you can experience 4 very different roles over the course of 2 years, which is great for trying to understand a company as large as Cisco. The variety of roles is clearly a plus as you are able to preference which areas interest you as you move throughout your time in the program.
-Generally, the expectations from your teams are within reason but provide a challenge at least in my experience. Learning is encouraged and mistakes are seen as an opportunity to grow rather than a reason for criticism.
-The program itself feels like a family of sorts that you can relate with people in the same boat as yourself early in career. This makes for a great support system and provides an automatic resource for general questions.
Cons:
-Sometimes timing of role responsibilities and additional program expectations can overlap which can create a challenge; however, these are chances to exercise time management.
-Transitions can be a little tricky to manage due to turnover of roles (some new ones can be added and others) so some processes aren't as clearly defined. Generally business partners are understanding though and there's always help to get you up to speed.

Pros: WebEx is a SaaS leader - and has market leadership in web conferencing space. Lots of potential as SaaS model truly takes off. WebEx encourages rapid pace of innovation - and is somewhat gratifying to see things shape up without much of red tape. Most people are very talented. Ever since Cisco has bought WebEx, there is a marked increase in the quality of upper management - in terms of their ability to aim big and execute. Best thing about WebEx - you do not have to pay for Web meetings - and online meetings are so effective to bring together geographically distributed teams.
Cons:
Lack of respect for people and their personal life, and lack of professionalism (Especially within the product organization). 
WebEx culture can be described as somewhat chaotic. Disagreements / criticisms are discouraged - and the culture encourages people to rally around the Kool-aid of their bosses. Work-life balance is way tilted towards work, and the management takes it for granted. As an organization, WebEx tries to achieve more at the cost of quality of the product, and the quality of the life of the people who build the product. There are still remnants of fiefdoms from pre-Cisco time. Geographically dispersed teams can be challenging  - in terms of working across different time zones, cultural differences and language differences.

Pros: The ability to work remote if necessary. The extensive benefits for an employee including 401K matching and Employee Assistance Program, and onsite health and fitness center. Many of the people I worked with as peers were intelligent and fun to work with
Cons: This company has changed dramatically over the past decade. Internally it can now be a very political environment where promotions and increases were awarded  to those who bought into empire building within business units and not people doing the real work essential to the success of the company. The focus on process and metrics is only effctive when everyone either agrees or is aware of the metric targets, without that it seems like evaluations are subjective and unfair. Anyone who had been managed out due to restructure is more likely to have been targeted for being more of a thinker than the management wants.

Pros: Great pay and benefits. My bonuses were extremely generous (though I earned it working extremely hard).  A lot of really smart people doing super cool things. The company is still really innovative. I had the pleasure of working in lots of new areas - emerging markets, emerging solutions - and the conversations we had with customers were very interesting. Solving unique problems for smart cities, connected health, education, workplace, etc. For the right role, I would consider working there again. Internal competitiveness at one time created a healthy let's get it done environment. Great collaboration tools that enable you to have really effective virtual meetings. "Be the customer" mentality - always having employees adopt new productivity enhancing tools. Telepresence rules!
Cons: Really political. Terrible gossip system. There used to be a mentor-y "we're in it together' feeling. It changed to more of a make yourself look good at the expense of other people culture.  Lost sight of what matters for awhile. Too many company priorities (at one point, there were 50 top priorities!)  Victim of tech jargon. Lots of big words to sound grandiose, but it didn't make sense in the end. I respect John Chambers a lot, and I have had chill bumps from some of his keynotes, but after awhile, it just sounded empty, and the same old messages over and over.

Pros:
Good cafeterias -- with both healthy choices and not-so-much.
Some nice buildings, although the nicer buildings have smaller cubicles.
Cons:
Cisco is an engineer-centric society, much to its own detriment.

Cisco had an HR department website instead of new-employee orientation.  Despite the steady stream of complaints from employees about the user hostility of the internal HR website, Cisco persisted in forcing its employees to rely on a highly unreliable internal HR website, much to the frustration of everyone involved.

Cisco management seemed hell-bent on working its employees days, nights, and weekends -- all the while chanting the Work-Life Balance buzzwords as hypocritical propaganda.

Other companies work hard to instill and encourage and maintain mutual respect so that each and every employee, from board room to mail room engage with kindness and respect.  Not Cisco.

Horrendous coffee.

Pros: It's Cisco. Great in terms of employee benefits, professionalism, and fair policies. Very good in terms of social presence (progressive, diverse), community engagement, social welfare, etc...  Large company with options to move around, grow, and gain experience. Salary/compensation tends to fall on the upper side of range. Large product/solution footprint that covers a lot of technology. 800lb gorilla with worldwide presence. Good reputation, Hallmark technology company, lots of things to build with and sell.
Cons: Big company with the classic downsides. Internal culture and drivers have been impacted over the last decade by rapid development and shareholder/profit pressures. Most innovation is now acquired and assimilated. Not so much a knock, but where the company is in its evolutional cycle. The result is constant fluctuation in strategy, priorities, organization, and management. Unfortunately, career advancement/survival these days too often is knowing what bandwagon to jump on, when to jump off, and when to blame someone else. Lot of hardworking talented people get flushed in the process with the regular LRs. Too many managers "manage up" and not down.

Pros: Flexible/home working, benefits. Work life balance.
Cons: Depending on what part of the company you work for then your working experiences are different. This is highly sales focussed company, Services are a poor relation and often driven with cost reductions. TAC are well funded thanks to lucrative support renewals. Cisco is far too US focussed, almost ALL the new VP's and SVP's are American, with American strategies which only work in the US. Cost reduction appears to be high on the agenda and this impacts all aspects for a number of years now. Morale is poor and the People Deal they published is farcical considering the number of layoffs they constantly keep making. Promotions have not been communicated or transparent for a long, long time. No clear or defined career ladder either, this depends on what accounts and projects you get attached to tbh. Cisco appears to be trying to regenerate into a more youthful company to reduce costs but have lost a tremendous amount of industry experience and skills in doing so. Innovation is primarily hardware focussed. Very poor long term strategy or investment in Services, where the financials take precedence over quality, efficiency and innovation. Remote workers are VERY remote, hardly getting to see colleagues at all for years. I never saw my Manager face to face for three years! Get used to days and days siting on Webex calls.

Cons: TC is pretty low compare to other tech company

Pros: Good work life balance. Allow you to work remotely
Cons: I joined with a good salary 5 years ago as a new grad out of college, and I have seen only ONE increment of 5% in the last 5 years. It was not like I was not doing good. They kept doing re-orgs and rotated me under different managers. Each manager said I needed to establish myself with him. And each one promised me a promotion next year which didnt happen. I saw other people in other groups getting promoted or salary hiked much faster and here I am slogging under one manager after another, sometimes doing junk work that the technical leads themselves do not want to take. I stayed on because they gave me flexibility to work from home which I needed as I was facing some family issues. I looked outside and landed up with an offer that directly gave me a 45% hike. Happy to get out of here finally! I would not advise young people to join Cisco unless they know they are getting the right pay, the right recognition and growth in their careers. Each group is different, not every group need to be like mine. But move out as soon as you find out you are stagnating or you are not being just-fully rewarded/promoted, within 6 months.

Pros: Engaging work and the ability to get involved with a diverse set of customers. People here are fun to work with.  The culture: extremely flexible work environment, great people, minimal focus on performance management (you can be a top performer with minimal effort), and a company that cares about your overall well being.
Cons: Compensation and career growth.  Cisco is HORRIBLE at rewarding employees (even if you are constantly told you are a top performer) which is causing many talented people to leave.  Focal cycles once a year at best that are funded to a level where they can only give you a 4% raise at most.  New hires today make more than people who have been here 5+ years.  The company is doing better than ever but this only translates to executive promotions and raises.  To get a raise you have to leave for a year and then you can get rehired at 2x your prior salary.

Pros: Work life balance and decent hike
Cons: There will be layoff often
